lines.text: Did you ever see the Medal of Honor?
No, Sir.
It's the most beautiful decoration of all, as it should be. I'd trade an ear for one any time, two in fact.
Excuse me, Sir, but I'd rather have the ear.
I became two men. One can't stand living in the same skin with the other.
If there's one piece of truth in your insect soul, I want it!
I wouldn't give him my sweat if he was dying of thirst.
What is courage? What is cowardice? This is the story of his search for an answer.
We're chasing one man, Pancho Villa, over some of the wildest country on earth. You can quote me as saying that the Punitive Expedition U.S. Army has him completely surrounded... on one side.
One act of cowardice doesn't make a man a coward forever, just as one act of bravery doesn't make a man a hero forever.
Heroes? Saints living in the desert? My God, they tried to rape me! And blackmail you! It's a wonder they haven't shot you already! No, Thorne, they're only men - and damned poor specimens at that!
I have less right than any man on earth to judge them.
Or to judge yourself either.

[pauses]
You may be right, what you say. They're human beings. But they're more than that. They have one thing in them that is a miracle and a mystery. It redeems them. They don't know what it is themselves, but they have it. I have to save it.
You really believe this?
[he nods]
If you do, Thorn, if you do... you may be worth all of them.

[of a hand-pumped railroad cart]
Ladies and gents, this is the Spitball Express. Heroes ride free;
[eyes Adelaide suggestively]
ladies at their own risk. As far as majors are concerned, the end of the line comes a lot closer than they think. All aboard!

[to Adelaide]
Lady, you're definitely too logical for a woman.

[after getting a boil on his backside lanced]
That didn't hurt a bit.
